name: Explosive Child Approach
summary: A collaborative problem-solving therapy designed to help children with chronic frustration, inflexibility, and explosive behavior by teaching skills in flexibility, frustration tolerance, and problem-solving.
description: The Explosive Child Approach, developed by Dr. Ross Greene and detailed in his book 'The Explosive Child,' is a therapeutic model emphasizing collaboration and proactive problem-solving between caregivers and children. Known formally as Collaborative & Proactive Solutions (CPS), this approach shifts away from traditional reward/punishment models and instead focuses on identifying and addressing underlying lagging skills. By involving children in identifying problems and working on mutually satisfying solutions, the approach reduces conflict, builds trust, and helps children develop self-regulation and problem-solving capacities.

contraindications: Families unable or unwilling to participate collaboratively
Situations requiring immediate crisis intervention only
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Safe and supportive, though challenging behaviors may initially increase during adjustment.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Moderate—supported by clinical research, case studies, and school-based applications.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Clinical studies demonstrate reductions in oppositional and explosive behavior, improved family relationships, and decreased parental stress with CPS approaches.

sections.text: The approach operates on the principle that 'kids do well if they can.' Explosive behavior arises not from lack of motivation but from lagging skills in flexibility, frustration tolerance, and problem-solving. By collaborating with children on identifying unsolved problems and brainstorming solutions, the approach builds skills while reducing conflict.

sections.preparation: Identify lagging skills and chronic unsolved problems using assessment tools (e.g., the Assessment of Lagging Skills and Unsolved Problems, ALSUP).
procedure: Plan A: Imposing adult will (least used).
Plan C: Temporarily setting aside lower-priority issues to reduce conflict.
Engage child in identifying problems and generating solutions together.
sections.frequency: Weekly sessions with therapist or coach; daily application by caregivers.
sections.duration: Typically 8–16 weeks, but ongoing integration at home/school.

sections.pre_session: Review unsolved problems and child’s recent behaviors.
sections.treatment_phase: Parent and therapist role-play CPS conversations; guided practice with child.
sections.post_session: Parents implement collaborative problem-solving strategies at home.

immediate: Improved parent insight into child’s needs

common: Initial resistance from child or parents

absolute: Acute psychiatric crises requiring immediate intervention

ideal_candidates: Children with chronic inflexibility and explosive behavior
Families seeking alternatives to strict behavioral management

practitioner: Therapists, counselors, or parent coaches trained in Collaborative & Proactive Solutions (CPS)
facility: Private practice, community mental health, school counseling

studies: Greene RW, Ablon JS. (2006). Treating Explosive Kids: The Collaborative Problem-Solving Approach.
Ollendick TH, Greene RW. (2014). Collaborative Problem Solving for children with ODD and severe irritability: A randomized clinical trial.
sections.limitations: Research base smaller than for CBT; requires significant caregiver involvement for success.

sections.insurance_coverage: Often covered as family therapy or behavioral intervention
sections.cost_effectiveness: Considered cost-effective given improvements in behavior and reduced family stress.

sections.autism: Useful in addressing rigidity and explosive behavior in children with autism spectrum disorders.
sections.adhd: Helps children with impulsivity and frustration tolerance deficits.

items: Approach emphasizes empathy and collaboration over control.
Success depends heavily on parent engagement and consistency.
Works best when integrated into daily routines at home and school.

seo.title: Explosive Child Approach: Collaborative Problem-Solving for Challenging Behaviors
seo.description: The Explosive Child Approach (CPS) helps parents and children reduce explosive outbursts by building flexibility, problem-solving skills, and emotional regulation through collaboration.
